qas.question: On which date were lawsuits filed against Harvard and Chapel Hill?
Who filed the lawsuits against the Universities?
Other than Asian students, who else was allegedly being discriminated against?
What is the Students for Fair Admissions an offshoot of?
What are the Universities waiting for before proceeding with the lawsuit?

answers.text: until the U.S. Supreme Court provides clarification of relevant law

qas.question: On which date were lawsuits filed with Harvard and Chapel Hill?
Who filed the lawsuits with the Universities?
Other than African students, who else was allegedly being discriminated against?
What is the Students for Fair Admissions not an offshoot of?

plausible_answers.text: until the U.S. Supreme Court provides clarification of relevant law by ruling

qas.question: What are the Universities waiting for after proceeding with the lawsuit?

context: On <a0_0><b5_0>November 17, 2014<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0><b6_0>Students for Fair Admissions<b6_0/><a1_0/>, an offshoot of the <a3_0><b8_0>Project on Fair Representation<b8_0/><a3_0/>, filed lawsuits in federal district court challenging the admissions practices of Harvard University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The UNC-Chapel Hill lawsuit alleges discrimination against <a2_0><b7_0>white<b7_0/><a2_0/> and Asian students, while the Harvard lawsuit focuses on discrimination against Asian applicants. Both universities requested the court to halt the lawsuits <a4_0><b9_0>until the U.S. Supreme Court provides clarification of relevant law<a4_0/> by ruling<b9_0/> in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin for the second time. This Supreme Court case will likely be decided in June 2016 or slightly earlier.
